slides.name: Introduction: Living and Non-living Things 1
slides.content:
**Isn't our planet a wonderful place? **

There are so many different **living things** out there - from the mighty **whale** to the humble **worm,** from the fantastic **toadstool** to the tiniest **bacterium! **

Try and think of **all** of the living things that you know about. You'll be thinking for a very** long time! **

slides.name: MCQ: Life Processes 1
slides.content: Which of the following processes is **NOT** required for something to be classified as **living?**
slides.explanation:
There are **eight** things that something must carry out to be classified as alive. These are:

Movement
Respiration
Sensitivity
Cells
Growth
Reproduction
Excretion
Nutrition

slides.name: MCQ: Living or Non-Living? 2
slides.content:
The robot above carries out **some** of the eight processes in **MRS C GREN,** but **not all of them.**

Is the robot **living** or **non-living?**
slides.explanation: If something carries out some but not all of the eight life processes described by MRS C GREN, it is classified as **non-living**.

slides.name: MCQ: Living or Non-Living? 1
slides.content:
Cows carry out **all** of the eight processes in **MRS C GREN.**

Is the cow **living** or **non-living?**
slides.explanation: If something carries out all of the eight life processes described by MRS C GREN, it is classified as **living.**

slides.name: MCQ: Living or Non-Living? 3
slides.content:
Mould carries out **all** of the eight processes in **MRS C GREN.**

Is mould **living** or **non-living?**
slides.explanation: If something carries out all of the eight life processes described by MRS C GREN, it is classified as **living.** Some things that you'd never think of can still be living!

slides.name: Drag and Drop: MRS C GREN 1
slides.content:
M: All or part of a living thing is able to [move].
R: Stands for [respiration]: this is how living things turn food and air into energy.
S: Living things are [sensitive] to things in their environment.
C: Living things are made up of cells.

slides.name: Drag and Drop: MRS C GREN 2
slides.content:
G: Living things grow, and therefore increase in [size] over time.
R: Living things can [reproduce], and some can have many offspring.
E: Living thing have to [excrete] waste from their bodies.
N: Living things take in and use [nutrients].

slides.name: MCQ: Life Processes 2
slides.content: What is the **acronym** for determining whether something is **living?**
slides.explanation: The acronym we use for determining whether something is living or not living is **MRS C GREN.**

slides.name: Long Answer: Fire
slides.content:
Is fire a **living thing** or a **non-living thing?**

Use **MRS C GREN** to **explain** your answer.
slides.answer: Fire is not a living thing because it does not carry out all seven processes described by MRS C GREN.
keywords: Fire is/is not a living thing because...

slides.name: Introduction: Living and Non-living Things 2
slides.content:
Our planet is also full of things that **aren't living.** 

**Rocks, water **and even the **chair** you are sitting on are all **non-living things!**

slides.name: Introduction: Living and Non-living Things 4
slides.content:
To determine whether a thing is **living** or **non-living,** we can look at some of its **characteristics** or **features**. 

There are **eight features** that things need to have for them to be **living.** Living things must have **ALL** of these features, otherwise they are **not living!**

slides.name: Introduction: Living and Non-living Things 5
slides.content:
We can remember these **eight features** by using the acronym:

**MRS C GREN.**

slides.name: Introduction: Movement 1
slides.content:
**Movement**

The first letter in **MRS C GREN,** 'M', stands for **Movement.** 

All living things **move.** Animals use **structures** like legs or wings to help them move.

slides.name: Introduction: Movement 2
slides.content:
What about **plants?** They don't move...do they? How come they're a **living thing? **

Actually, plants move too! They may not move their **whole bodies** (like animals do), but they can move **parts** of themselves, like when they move their leaves to **face the sun!**

slides.name: Introduction: Respiration
slides.content:
**Respiration**

We all need **energy** to live, and **respiration** is what helps us get it. 

Respiration converts the **food** we eat and the **air** we breathe into **energy!**

slides.name: Introduction: Sensitivity
slides.content:
**Sensitivity**

All **living things** are **sensitive** to the environment around them. 

Humans have **five main senses:** sight, hearing, taste, smell and touch.

slides.name: Introduction: Growth
slides.content:
**Growth** 

All **living things** **grow** as they get older. 

If they didn't, dogs would be puppies, trees would be seeds and you would be a baby for **your entire life!**

slides.name: Introduction: Reproduction
slides.content:
**Reproduction**

All **living things** are capable of **reproduction.**

Reproduction means that living things can produce **offspring,** or babies. You are the offspring of your parents, which means they **reproduced** to make you!

slides.name: Introduction: Excretion
slides.content:
**Excretion**

**Excretion** is the **removal of waste products** from the body. 

We humans do this every time we visit the **toilet,** otherwise known as peeing and pooping.

slides.name: Introduction: Nutrition
slides.content:
**Nutrition**

**Food** is amazing, but have you ever thought about **why** we eat it? 

Living things need **energy** to grow and move. As animals, we gain this energy by **eating food.** Other **living things** obtain it in **other ways.**

slides.name: Introduction: Cells
slides.content:
**Cells**

Every **living thing** is made up of **cells!**
